title: DFSV Commissioner on stopping violence against children | ABC NEWS
description: The Domestic, Sexual and Family Violence commissioner says a watchdog is needed to harmonise government responses to violence against children. Commissioner Micaela Cronin spoke on her recommendations for tackling the issue in an interview with ABC political reporter Claudia Long. *If you or anyone you know is affected by domestic, sexual and family violence, please contact support services:* *1800 RESPECT* 1800 737 732 *FULL STOP AUSTRALIA* 1800 385 578 *BRAVEHEARTS* 1800 272 831 *LIFELINE* 131 114 Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE Read more here: https://www.abc.net.au/news/2025-10-30/violence-against-women-national-watchdog-micaela-cronin/105949568  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: ACT closes 'legal loophole' making institutions more liable for child sexual abuse | ABC NEWS
description: The ACT has become the first jurisdiction to pass legislation expanding the liability of churches, sporting groups and other organisations to include the actions of paedophiles.  The case arose after the High Court found the Catholic Church was not vicariously liable for the actions of a paedophile priest because his arrangements were only akin to employment.  A Canberra survivor of child sexual abuse and their lawyer have welcomed the legislation. title: Police drain dam in search for missing four-year-old boy Gus | ABC News
description: Police say they have finished searching a dam on a South Australian outback property where four-year-old Gus went missing more than a month ago, but there has been no signs of the four-year-old boy.  They said they drained 3.2 million litres of water from the dam and cleared weed beds on Friday but nothing of significance was found.  Gus was last seen playing at his family's vast and isolated sheep station, about 40 kilometres south of Yunta on September 27. description: Hundreds of thousands of Israel’s conservative ultra-Orthodox Jewish community have shut down one of the country’s busiest junctions, protesting moves to force them to serve in the military. title: High Country killer Greg Lynn faces court to appeal murder conviction | ABC NEWS
description: A Melbourne court has been hearing submissions on whether to quash Greg Lynn's murder conviction for the death of Carol Clay. Carol and her companion Russell Hill died at a remote campsite in Victoria's High Country in March, 2020. Lynn admitted to covering up evidence after the pair died, including burning the bodies, but the convicted killer insists their deaths were accidental. title: Prince Andrew stripped of title and told to leave Royal Lodge | ABC NEWS
description: King Charles will strip Prince Andrew of his royal titles and remove him from the Royal Lodge on the grounds of Windsor, according to an announcement made by Buckingham Palace.  The statement said formal notice was given to Andrew that he would need to surrender the lease of his mansion and move to private accommodation.  He will now be known as Andrew Mountbatten Windsor and not as a prince. The Gellung Warl body will be consulted on laws and policies affecting Indigenous people. title: US Ambassador interrupted by Cuba at UN | ABC NEWS
description: US Ambassador to the UN Mike Waltz was interrupted during a speech at the United Nations General Assembly by the Foreign Minister of Cuba, Bruno Rodriguez.   The General Assembly were due to vote on whether to condemn the United States' economic restrictions on Cuba.   "Mr Waltz, this is the United Nations General Assembly," Mr Rodriguez said. "It's not a Signal chat. Nor is it the House of Representatives."   He also said Mr Waltz was speaking in an "uncivilised, crude and gross way".  But Mr Waltz's speech was unable to convince many countries, with the UN General Assembly voting 165-7, with 12 abstentions to condemn the US economic embargo against Cuba. title: France updates law defining rape | ABC NEWS
description: Senators approved changes to France's rape law on Wednesday to include consent, bringing the legislation more into line with more than a dozen other European countries in a move that was given new impetus by the Gisèle Pelicot mass rape trial.  French criminal law has until now defined rape as a penetrative act or oral sex act committed on someone using "violence, coercion, threat or surprise".   It did not make clear mention of the need for consent and prosecutors had to prove the intention to rape to secure a guilty verdict.  Reporting by Reuters.  🎥 Video by Sohani Goonetillake.
